page.title: 15WILDLIFE UNDER THREAT
page.content: THE COUNTRYSIDE TO THE EAST OF THE TOWN IS DIVIDED INTO TWO BY ACLE NEW ROAD.TO THE NORTH OF THE ROAD THE LAND HAS BEEN EXTENSIVELY DRAINED AND PUT DOWN TO CEREALS.TO THE SOUTH THE LAND STILL RETAINS SOME OF ITS ORIGINAL CHARACTER,ALTHOUGH FURTHER DRAINAGE IS TAKING PLACE,RESULTING IN THE INEVITABLE LOSS OF NATURAL HABITATS. DURING THE PAST YEAR THE INSTALLATION OF NEW LAND DRAINS NEAR THE STRACEY ARMS INN HAVE REDUCED TUNSTALL DYKE (WHICH ONCE CARRIED WHERRY TRAFFIC) TO A SHALLOW TRICKLE.AS THE WATER TABLE HAS DROPPED ,LARGE AREAS OF REED SWAMP HAVE DISAPPEARED,DIMINISHING THE ALREADY LIMITED BREEDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR SCARCE SPECIES LIKE BEARDED TITS, WATER RAILS AND NEWTS. WATER ENRICHMENT HAS LONG BEEN A PROBLEM IN BROADLAND AND LITTLE EVIDENCE EXISTS TO SUGGEST IT IS BEING
